nodes.bodyText: Can you please use the same assertions (JUnit) used below? import static org.junit.Assert.assertThat

It was intentional the use of assertj Assertions.assertThat() instead of junit Assert.assertThat, because in my opinion it gives a cleaner way to understand what it is being asserted
Here is an interesting article about that: https://dzone.com/articles/the-benefit-of-using-assertthat-over-other-assert
Please let me know your opinion
@vpellegrino Considering it was intentional, it's fine for me!
@vpellegrino Is it possibile to add a test for this method makeItem()?
@yesamer sure, I am going to enrich already existing test set

I am not less expert, so tried to compile this less file in http://beautifytools.com/less-compiler.php and got some messages about 'overqualified' elements. Is that fine? May be false positives for sure, really just asking.

@jomarko thank you for your observation & question.
Yes, the online LESS compiler it is suggesting that for each element li.class-name, the element (li) presence it is not necessary.
This is true also for CSS rules.
My approach was to leave rules as-is and to add newer ones, maintaining the same format.
To be honest, I am not sure if any automation test could be impacted by removal of element in such rules, so I'd leave the situation as is.
What is your opinion?
hmm, yes, I think as you added some 'rules' to existing file we can keep existing format to not bring confusion
